text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page composition organized as a three-by-three grid of miniatures with no surrounding text; panels are separated by decorative frames and consistent margins; central scene larger vertically but integrated into grid; wide outer margins left blank.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold backgrounds reserved for all panels to signify divine or typological importance; ultramarine and vermilion alternate in garments to denote hierarchy of figures; white highlights layered over pigments to create volume; green used for secondary drapery and landscape; borders feature alternating blue and red panels with gold bezants.

features: Central panel emphasized by a larger arch frame
Vertical and horizontal axes of symmetry
Uniform panel size except central slightly taller

decorative_elements: Gold dotted backgrounds in all frames
Green and blue architectural arch framing central scene
Alternating red and blue panel borders with gold insets
Inscribed scroll bands in each narrative panel
Micro-architectural frames with pilasters and capitals

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in dark brown ink with consistent line weight, fine internal detailing for facial features
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal hatching; modeling achieved through layered pigments and white highlights on drapery folds
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling of figures by importance, overlapping forms to imply depth, no vanishing-point perspective

reading_order: Left to right across top row
then middle row left to right
then bottom row left to right

content_theme.scene_description: The central panel depicts three Marys at the empty tomb of Christ. A seated angel, robed in white with gold highlighting and outspread wings, addresses the two standing women, who wear long mantles of green and red edged in gold. The sarcophagus lid rests at an angle on a green base patterned with white dots. The angel’s right hand is raised in benediction, while a scroll unfurls at his feet inscribed “Nolite timere” in black ink. The two women appear attentive: one clasps her hands in prayer, the other leans forward. The background is burnished gold with subtle punchwork dots. The architectural frame is a green arch with a patterned vault above, supported by twin columns with foliate capitals. A decorative band of alternating blue and gold squares surrounds the arch. White highlights accentuate drapery folds and facial modeling, creating a sense of volume within the flat gold ground.

religious: Christ healing miracles in top panels

natural: Stylized grass base in central panel

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform thickness and finely prepared smooth surface; evidence of meticulous scraping and pumicing; quire structure suggests quaternion gatherings.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent overall condition; pigments remain vibrant with minimal oxidation; gold leaf well-adhered with minor surface abrasion; no significant cockling; edges show slight handling wear.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in backgrounds
Visible underdrawing in brown pigment under white highlights
Regular ruling pattern discernible under UV
Punchwork dot pattern in gold grounds
Layered pigment application with fine brush strokes

secondary_functions: Display of patron’s wealth and piety
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Cathedral clergy and high-ranking ecclesiastical patrons

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This full-page grid miniature likely originates from a late 12th-century French Gospel Book or liturgical manuscript produced in a cathedral workshop. The uniform use of burnished gold backgrounds and punchwork, combined with high-quality ultramarine and vermilion pigments, reflects royal or episcopal patronage and the resources of a major scriptorium. Stylistically, the composition balances Romanesque solidity with emerging Gothic expressiveness in drapery folds and facial features, indicating a transitional phase influenced by the Parisian and Tours illuminators. The integration of New Testament miracles in the upper and middle registers with Old Testament prefigurations—Samson, David—and the pelican allegory beneath the central Resurrection scene articulates a typological program linking Christ’s redemptive acts across biblical history. This iconographic scheme underscores the theological emphasis on Christ’s victory over death, a popular theme in liturgical contexts during Eastertide. Comparative analysis with the Winchester Bible and the Bury St. Edmunds Psalter suggests shared architectural framing devices and color palettes, though this manuscript exhibits greater linear precision and more restrained ornamentation. The collaborative execution, visible through multiple hands in facial types and drapery treatment, exemplifies standard workshop practice. Technically, the manuscript demonstrates sophisticated layering of pigments and meticulous gesso modeling, marking it as a significant example of late Romanesque to early Gothic illumination.
